title: How to Organize Your Fabric Stash

steps.headline: Decide how you’d like to group your fabrics.
steps.description: Maybe you want to sort them by fabric type, such as silks, denims, cottons, flannels, etc. You can also choose to sort the fabric by color, pattern, or print design. For example, group all of the polka dot fabric together, or all of the fabric with a floral design. You can color-code your fabric by shades, such as starting with green and then moving on to turquoise, light blue, blue, and navy. Consider grouping all of your holiday-themed fabrics together.

steps.headline: Cut your fabrics into usable sizes and shapes.
steps.description: If you have fabric that has shapes cut out of it or unusable scraps attached, cut these off. This will make folding your fabric much easier and your fabric will be ready to use once you pull it out. You can set aside any scraps that you’d like to use and store them with other scraps. Use fabric scissors to cut the fabric, or scissors sharp enough to cut through the fabric without causing the edges to fray.

steps.headline: Fold your fabric so that all of it is the same size.
steps.description: This makes your fabrics much more visually appealing if they’re being displayed, as well as easier to sort through if they’re hidden away. Decide how wide and long you’d like your fabric to be when folded, and use a ruler to help you measure and fold each piece. The ruler is especially helpful for making sharp, even folds. Place the ruler on the inside of the fabric, and then fold over the ruler, pulling the fabric until it's taut against the ruler.

steps.headline: Use a swatch system to help you keep track of your fabrics.
steps.description: Cut out 1-inch (2.5 cm) squares of fabric and attach them to paper swatches. You can attach the swatches to a ribbon or chain, and you’ll be able to sort through your fabrics easily to see which ones you have. You can write down where the fabric is located, such as in which drawer or box, or how many inches or yards of it you have on the swatch as well.

steps.headline: Put your fabrics in plastic tubs to keep them clean.
steps.description: This is a great option if you’re storing fabric long-term, but it’s also useful for keeping dust and dirt off of your fabrics. You can fold your fabrics and place them flat against the tub’s bottom, or you can set them up vertically to peruse the different fabrics easily.

steps.headline: Place fabric in canvas boxes for easy access.
steps.description:
You can buy canvas storage cubes that are relatively cheap and come in an assortment of colors. Set up the canvas boxes on a regular shelf that’s roughly 1 foot (30 cm) tall to fit the boxes, or you can purchase a cube shelf that’s designed specifically to hold the canvas cubes. Label each canvas box so that you know what type of fabric is in them. For example, the labels might read “Florals,” “Gingham,” or “Silks.”
You could even buy storage cubes in specific colors, such as pink, yellow, and green, and then store your pink, yellow, and green fabrics in a corresponding cube.

steps.headline: Keep your fabric in drawers for a tidy option.
steps.description: If you have a spare dresser drawer or even a set of plastic drawers, fold your fabric neatly and place it in the drawers. Set up the fabric so that it’s positioned vertically instead of horizontally in the drawer — this will allow you to see all of the different fabrics at once. You could have 1 drawer for all blue fabrics, 1 for all green fabrics, and so on. You can also create a holiday drawer and set up all of your holiday-themed fabrics in 1 drawer for easy access.

steps.headline: File your fabric away in a file cabinet or box if you have smaller pieces.
steps.description: Use file cabinet dividers to store your fabrics in a file cabinet. Fold each piece of fabric so that it fits in the divider, and place it neatly inside. You can add labels to the dividers to flip through the file cabinet easily and know where to look for your fabrics. This works well for smaller lengths and quantities of fabric.

steps.headline: Keep fabrics hidden under a cloth-covered table to save space.
steps.description: If you want your fabrics accessible but not seen, store them in bins, drawers, or file folders and tuck them away under a table. Place a tablecloth over the table that’s long enough to almost reach the bottom of the floor, and your fabric stash will be tidily hidden away. If you have extra space under a desk, this could be a great spot for hiding your fabrics.

steps.headline: Store your fabrics on a cubby or regular shelf for a stackable option.
steps.description: A cubby shelf will have a cube structure, perfect for shorter fabrics. A regular shelf will be able to hold an entire bolt of fabric, perfect for storing larger amounts. You can store all of your flannels on 1 shelf, all of your cottons on another, and so on. You could even consider having a custom shelf made to fit your desired specifications.

steps.headline: Display your fabrics on a magazine rack for smaller quantities.
steps.description: Fold your fabrics so that they can fit on the rack of a standing magazine rack and set each piece of fabric over the rack’s bars. Not only is this aesthetically pleasing, but it’ll make finding and grabbing the fabric you need super easy. You can find standing magazine racks online.

steps.headline: Use a curtain rod to hang your fabrics to flip through them easily.
steps.description: While this method is especially great for longer fabrics, it works well with all sizes. Use plastic or metal pants hanger clips to hook the fabrics onto the curtain rod. Organize them however you’d like, and then flip through the fabrics easily.

steps.headline: Place fabric in clear photo boxes to protect the fabrics.
steps.description: For advanced organizing, buy a bunch of clear photo boxes and separate your fabrics into each one. You can have 1 for all of your black fabrics, 1 for all of your textured fabrics, etc. Stack the photo boxes on top of each other to store them efficiently. When storing the fabric in the boxes, you can either place each piece flat against the bottom or set them up vertically so that you can see a sample of each fabric.

steps.headline: Keep tiny scraps in an open bowl for easy access.
steps.description: Find a bowl large enough to accommodate all of your scraps. Since they’re all thrown together, you’ll have to look through the bowl to find the scraps you want. Use a decorative bowl to turn your fabric scraps into a creative focal point in the room.

steps.headline: Put scraps in a cassette rack for a creative solution.
steps.description: If you have scraps that are a little bit larger, fold each one up and place it in a section of a cassette rack. You can create rows of similar groupings, such as fabric types, colors, or patterns.

steps.headline: Fold up scraps and place them in page protectors to store in a binder.
steps.description: You’ll be able to flip right through the binder to find the scraps you want, and they won’t take up very much space. Slide each scrap into a clear, plastic page protector, and then clip all the pages into an empty binder. If desired, you can use dividers to label different sections of your scraps, like “Halloween Scraps,” or “Animal Fabric,” so that you can easily find them.

steps.headline: Store ribbon and extra small scraps in clear jars.
steps.description: Find a clear candy jar or large mason jar from a craft store or big box store. You can put all of your scraps in the jar and put on a lid, which will keep dust and dirt out of the fabric. Make sure you use a jar that’s big enough for your hand to reach in and pull out the scraps.

steps.headline: Use an over-the-door organizer to store your scraps tidily.
steps.description: If you have lots of scraps that can be organized into separate groupings, over-the-door organizers are a perfect storage option. Put all the striped scraps in 1 section, all the purples in another, and so on. Since the organizer is clear, you’ll be able to easily pick out the scraps you’re looking for.
